narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Question 2 - we usually just have a group discussion so there is no formal presentation of the material covered.Question 3 - we have not had any out of class assignments yet.

It is a bit hard to evaluate this course since it is still ongoing and experimental in set up as a 1 credit and 3 credit class. One credit students are only responsible for one reading but that can make discussion with guest lecturers is a bit difficult.Video conferencing seminar was very cool. This course will be easier to evaluate in the spring when full series is complete.
Declined to answer questions as I felt they were not very relevant to this particular class, being a speaker series and discussion session.
Hard to rate this class as it is primarily attending lectures here and there.

(1) There are a lot more readings than we were told there would be, so it's hard to finish them all before class.(4) The workload gets heavier in the second part of the class, which takes place next semester.

Given that this course is mid-stream, I am trying to reserve judgment. In a very complex and multidisciplinary field like urbanization, the balance has been generally great. It is a unique format for a class, and I wish that we had more class time and substantive discussion time, but I hope that these will coalesce in the second semester.My full evaluation will be completed when we finish in the spring; I've left all the other questions blank.
we only had 4 classes so far, I don't feel that I am able to make many of the valuations at this point.
Outside lecturers; various topics; different view points.
The material. I'm very excited about the material we are covering and that FES is finally getting an urban focus into the curriculum.The guest lecturers so far have been excellent.
guest lectures and disjointed vantages of the subject at large
get contact with several professors in this area through lectures and after-class interaction.
Exposure to different kinds of research pertaining to urbanization.
The accepting and open atmosphere for the sharing of ideas. Discussion is strongly encouraged. The instructors do not try to prove students wrong or otherwise inhibit contribution.
Variety of lecturers
get exposed to different ideas and lectures on urban issues

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More in-depth analysis of problems.

The course was extremely disorganized at the beginning and students had little understanding of what to expect - even in terms of days/times to meet, work load, credits ,etc. I understand that it's a new class but there were a lot of new classes offered this semester and this was the least organized kicking off. Now it seems fine and things are running much more smoothly.Maybe ask the lecturers to really anticipate/know the audience. Some of the presenters covered basic info that they did not need to cover. Maybe the professors could tell them ahead of time what the basic level of understanding is in the class of certain issues (ie pop growth, climate change, water etc)
connections between lectures

I take very little away from the discussions. Many organizational elements are lacking. For example, student work expectations were emerged unexpectedly as the course progressed. For example, 1 credit students went from being expected to attend class and do the readings to facilitate and record an interview and then edit the footage. Little details are overlooked; despite repeat requests to the TA, the updated syllabus was never posted to the class server.
I understand that this is the first year of the class, but I felt it needed more structure, especially in the discussion sessions. The class so far has felt very broad and rather vague.
CommunicationFiguring out assignments prior to semesterVideo editing and interviews take time to make them good....worth more than .5 credit.

Organization needs improvement. It is clear that it is being put together as we go. Information needs to be clear and available and not decided on during class time.The guest speakers should challenge us more, show us the guts of their research, not the "public interest" version.
lack of continuity between lectures, or integration of reading materials

The amount of time given to student discussion of the material could be increased. The level of student discussion might be improved if done in the absence of the guest lecturer and professor, with just the TA, to allow students to unselfconsciously dig into the material.

The various lectures are not tied together. I do not feel like I am greatly enhancing my knowledge of urban systems because there is no way to tie all the lectures together - ie a paper, test, presentation, etc. This is greatly needed.

More regular reminders about what time the course is meeting each week (since it changes, quite confusingly, each time) and which articles are most important to read (the revised syllabus with reading assignments still has not been posted).
A lot about new development and mega-cities. Nothing about urban slums or environmental problems associated.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Have not requested help yet. The TA can be slow to respond to basic requests like posting readings and presentations to classes v2.
NA
Have not sought additional help
Peter is very engaged, but sometimes takes too much time from the discussion. Professor Chertow's style of short questions and responses intended to spark students and the guests are a good model.
Peter could do a better job connecting with students and shortening his comments so they are less abstract and more understandable.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course is very relevant to my field of study.
introduces good dialogue on the importance of informed urbanization

I'm taking the class because I consider urban areas to be important in regards to numerous environmental, social, and health impacts. It is helpful for me to get exposure to ideas presented in the readings and guest lecture presentations as I identify potential areas for future work.
interested in urban planning
I am interested in urbanization and sustainable development.
I have some interests in urban issues, and hope this class can open up opportunities for me to explore more in this matter

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The one-credit course delivers something interesting, but not requires much homework to do.
To learn more abut urbanization and impacts, esp. re: climate change.
to learn different vantages on the subject at large
One of the few courses offered discussing urban systems and covering a variety of subjects. Exciting material.
Seemed like an opportunity to hear some interesting speakers.
Because of my interest in urban development.
interests

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: So far, yes!!
yes
Somewhat
I wish it was more rigorous. Students often do a great job of raising hard questions, I want the guests to really engage.
So far its been ok though I think there could be more cohesion. The speakers that have come in so far are great.
So far I have not been wowed by any of the presentations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: So far, yes!!
yes
We shall see...it's not over yet...

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: So far, it's a great class!
this is a lecture based seminar series with minimal guidance otherwise
It's a course in development, so they'll likely work out some kinks next year.
